title: How to differentiate between philosophy and psychology - Quora

response.answer_text: TL;DR: philosophy and psychology have developed their own methods towards seeking the ‘truth’ but essentially they are trying to achieve the same objective A lot of answers here seem to be from either philosophers or psychologists keen on playing turf wars. As a generalist I’m coming from a different viewpoint. I would beg to disagree with @Robert Sacerich that the disciplines share very little overlap. This is a viewpoint that stems from modern academia, which tends to stratify and divide; hence our higher education system today promotes depth rather than breadth as a virtue. But these are artificial institutional constructs, not epistemological ones. Ancient and modern practices The founders of Western philosophy saw things in a different light. Philosophy back then was regarded in its broadest definition - a love ‘philos’ of wisdom ‘sophia’. Hence Aristotle would today be equally considered a botanist, biologist, physicist, political scientist, economist, as well as a psychologist and philosopher. In a more explicit, modern setting, CBT (cognitive behavioural therapy), a leading evidence-based therapy, is derived from behavioural and cognitive therapy. But CBT’s founders, Ellis and Beck based their practice on principles derived from the ancient philosophical school of Stoicism. (see Stoic Philosophy and Scientific Research ) The century of the brain Moving into the 21st century, the gap between psychology and philosophy is narrowing even further as we make more advances into scientific understanding of the brain and cognition. Neuroscience, behavioural economics, and evolutionary psychology are providing fascinating insights into the mechanics of how we view and experience the world, learn, interact and make decisions. One striking example of these interdisciplinary overlaps are philosophy’s presentation of logical fallacies, psychology’s presentation of cognitive biases, and economics’ take on (Kahneman’s) fast and slow thinking. In my mind, psychology and philosophy are just different in-roads to a very basic underlying motivation - understanding the human condition. As Buckminster Fuller once said, academics are very good at drilling a very deep and narrow whole into their chosen discipline. But when they burrow down further than anyone else in their field and look upwards, all they can see is a tiny speck of the sky above.

Philosophy cares about sound reasoning. In philosophy before you make any claims you must learn how to reason, and how the "shape" of an argument makes it worth considering, or not, etc. You mostly argue about things you cannot test experimentally, but the training is supposed to keep you from going too far off track into absurdity. Philosophers pretty much argue with each other, and build off each others' ideas. However, they all tend to know how to do it right. In academic philosophy personal attacks are not going to be taken seriously. It's all about the worth of the idea. Going a little bit off topic because people have said that the study of the mind falls under psychology: there's actually something called philosophy of mind that argues about how we could possibly think, whether or not our minds and our brains are one and the same, etc. It's pretty cool because a lot of philosophers have offered up colorful thought experiments to illustrate their theories. Look up the "Chinese Nation" experiment as an example. Psychology developed from a mass of different social attitudes and trends (e.g., poststructuralism), and has a lot of conjecture and badly designed (sometimes unethical) studies in its past. By its nature it cannot be rigorous, especially in clinical settings, because you often have a single professional making judgment calls. While he or she may be very educated and sharp, there will be bias and other limitations. I hope that soon we will be able to rely more and more on neuroscience and brain imaging to study what we refer to as the human mind. Disclaimer: My answer is biased.

First, psychology begins as animal psychology. This was true in the days of Aristotle, but it is equally true today. When we study psychology in college, we often begin with rats, cats and dogs. The physiology of the psyche is crucial to a further grasp of the topic. Philosophy has no such beginning. Philosophy is based entirely on Free Thought. While many “psychologists” have doubted that Free Thought exists, this was never proposed when Philosophy began. Human psychology moves beyond physiology only slowly. It might begin with individual development, first of the infant in response to the mother and the family, and then to the stages of psycho-sexual development — the oral stage, the stage of toilet training, then puberty, adolescence, and then adulthood, for example. Again — Philosophy does not proceed in that way. Philosophy began with the postulate of Free Thought, of Freedom, of Free Will, of Reason as the starting point, and with Reason’s exploration of the outer and inner worlds. We might say, then, that Philosophy is about adults only — but it is more than that. It is promoted by adults only, but it also reaches beyond the Physical Realm. To clarify — Philosophy does not deny or reject the Physical Realm, or even minimize it — but Philosophy does not limit itself to the Physical Realm. From the very beginning of Philosophy — from the days of Socrates (400 BC), the emphasis was on intangible, invisible realities — not of Religion — but of Logic, Ethics and Aesthetics. The basic concepts of Philosophy (per Socrates and Plato) included the following “invisible” yet Eternal Ideals: Virtue, Duty, Morality, the Right, the Good, the Beautiful, Wisdom, Courage and Justice. This was the starting point of Philosophy. Defending these concepts — in the face of tyrants who denied them all with violence — even to the point of killing Socrates — this was the original project of Philosophy.

The spirit of inquiry is common to both, the methodologies may differ but they often overlap to a certain extent (e.g., contemplation with introspection, ethics and moral development). The very words are telling. Philosophy, ‘love of wisdom,’ was supposedly coined by the Greek mathematician and mystic Pythagoras who lived during the 4th and 5th centuries BCE. The first to use the word psychology, ‘study of the psyche,’ was Rudolph Göckel, a German Scholastic philosopher who lived in the 16th and 17th centuries AD. There are similarities and differences in these fields but psychology has endeavored to become a science and separate itself from the fields of philosophy and theology in which the psyche was regarded strictly as a metaphysical datum. Psychology attempts to regard the psyche to an empirical phenomenon. Unfortunately for the promulgators of reductionistic and materialistic psychology, the psyche, soul, or mind is a non-physical phenomena. All that can be quantified as empirical science is the closely associated phenomena of behavior and brain functions that correspond to states of consciousness. The brain however is not the mind. Perhaps the largest divide in psychology is made by the philosophical categories of materialism versus idealism where in the former school consciousness is a product of matter and in the latter school matter is a product of [Universal] mind. In this sense the modern notion of psychology is permeated by a divide that harkens back to the philosophers Aristotle and his teacher Plato, respectively. While there is a PsyD (Doctor of Psychology) degree, the majority of doctorates in psychology is the Doctor of Philosophy (PhD) degree IN psychology. Most psychologists I’ve met do not take this degree literally or identify themselves as Doctors of Philosophy. While experimental psychology and Behaviorism (in which some proponents actually deny the existence of mind) are skewed to the materialistic side of the psychology continuum, Transpersonal Psychology includes philosophical (including metaphysics), and spiritual idioms in its fold. Philosophy is not as well known as psychology is in this century. Most people have some idea that psychologists are clinicians of a sort helping with mental and emotional issues. But ask the person on the street what philosophy is or what a philosopher does and one is likely to elicit an embarrassed shrug.

I've a very thin idea about conceptual difference. You can say almost an outline idea (without going deep down). I'm sharing the details here. Let's check. Philosophy Philosophy, derived from the Greek word ‘philosophia,’ translates literally to ‘love of wisdom'. Philosophy is the study of general and fundamental problems that concern concrete matters such as values, existence, knowledge, reason, and language. Methods of philosophical examination include questioning, critical analysis, and rational debates. Philosophical questions that have been posed in the past include: is it possible to know anything and prove it? What is most real, and what is the meaning of life?However, philosophy is also concerned with more concrete questions such as: do humans have free will, and what is the best way to live a life? Psychology Psychology, derived from the Greek word ‘psychologia’ translates literally to ‘the study of human spirit.’ Psychology is the study of the human mind and human behaviour. It incorporates the examination of both conscious and unconscious experiences, as well as the interactions between thoughts, feelings, and behaviours. Psychology is an academic discipline and applied science, which seeks to understand the role of mental processes in human behaviour, whilst also exploring the physiological and biological functions that underpin cognitive processing and behaviour. Concepts explored by psychologists include perception, cognition, attention, emotion, intelligence, phenomenology, motivation, brain functioning, personality, behaviour, relationships, and resilience. Methods of empirical psychological investigation include experimental studies to infer causal and correlational relationships between distinct variables. Differences Between the Two Practices Philosophy arguably underpins all sciences, including psychology, and thus both disciplines overlap to some extent. However, although both bodies of knowledge examine people and life, the aspects each discipline focuses on, is considerably different. That is, while philosophy attempts to understand the existence of human life, psychology attempts to understand human behaviour. Apart from the topics that each area covers, philosophy and psychology also differ in terms of the methods they use to answer questions. Philosophy looks into areas such as life after death through questions and answers, and will never produce a single, correct answer. Contrastingly, psychology uses scientific method to understand human behaviour. This involves hypothesis testing that result in logical conclusions, supported by both observations and physical data. Furthermore, philosophy and psychology differ in employment opportunities. Philosophy majors can be employed as teachers, researchers, authors, and academic speakers. Contrastingly, psychologists are able to work across a wide array of fields. They can become clinical psychologists who diagnose and treat mental health conditions, or they can become counselling psychologists who provide people with advice on different issues. Psychologists can also become academic speakers, tertiary education lecturers, authors, and researchers.

Philosophy for centuries was based on reason, logic and rationality; a set of reasons or a logical basis for a course of action or a particular belief. During much of this time it dealt with metaphysics, which in turn studied ontology; the nature of Being, and Epistemology; how we know what we know, or the nature knowledge. It was devoid of empirical observation of any kind leading to factual confirmable results. However, many of it assumptions became established truth for millenia. Aristotle’s studies formed a basis for a move to studying by observation, that were actually reasoned guesswork rather than factual accounts, Plato put forward a theory of rational universals without any foundation in empirical factuality. Contemporary realism and idealism still assumes many of the original concepts of earlier metaphysics, but in the main philosophy has moved on, approaching the subject in various other ways; Such as Descartes rationalism, Kant’s ethical idealism, existentialism, phenomenology, pragmatism, analytic philosophy, continental philosophy, political philosophy and more recently psychological philosophy. Up until the late twentieth century seeking understanding philosophically in psychology was an anathema. However, with the advent of neurological and other breakthrough psychological studies some, but not all philosophers now combine philosophy with aspects of psychology. Libet* in the twentieth century and other psychologist discovered that up to either 300 microseconds, by one account and ten seconds by another, our decisions, those we maintain we made by free cwill, have been proven to be unfounded and are nothing of the sort. this has put the cat among the pigeons and lead to a marriage of sorts between philosophy and psychology. It lead many philosophers having to take these new accounts in their thinking,. An anathema for rationalists and idealists going against everything they hold to be true.. *See Libet, studies on free will on the internet for further information of these studies
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Gyselle Hernandez Salmeron

response.answer_text: Philosophy-science, the subject of research which is almost limitless area of knowledge and ideas about man and humanity in General, and about the world around them in the broadest sense; worldview, striving for knowledge of all things. Psychology-the science that studies the mechanisms and patterns of mental activity. for content↑ Comparison Philosophy, which emerged several millennia ago, is a phenomenon much more ancient than psychology. The philosophy is even hard to call it science (against this objection some philosophers), so it is a comprehensive way of understanding reality. Psychology, as well as many other Sciences, was closely connected with philosophy and only in the middle of the XIX century separated into an independent teaching. One of the main tasks of philosophy can be called the comprehension of consciousness as the largest worldview category. The psychology divides the mind into many separate elements: memory, thinking, will, perception, imagination, etc. Consciousness is just one of the types of mental activities, along with the unconscious. Philosophy discovers how consciousness (the sphere of spirit) interacts with the physical, the material. Psychology is unable to solve this problem, as well as to answer the question of where the spiritual came from in General. Here psychology is inferior to philosophy in matters of spirituality based on this worldview as its basis. Psychology can only describe the successive stages of consciousness formation in an individual, substantiates mental actions, helps to form mental skills, analyzes the state of a person. Therefore, we can say that psychology cannot exist without philosophy, while philosophy does not rely on psychology in its calculations. A psychologist should be a philosopher, but a philosopher does not need to know psychology. There is a kind of paradox: born as a science of the soul (psyche – "soul" in Greek), psychology then began to study the inner world of man, especially character, behavior and thinking. In fact, psychology is the science of the soul, which does not study the soul, because this substance is elusive. The original subject of comprehension of philosophy was the nature, then in the center of attention there was a ratio "the person – the world". His philosophy considers from different sides, answering the questions: "What is it?""Why so?"Psychology faces other tasks: it finds out how to change the current state of things, what are the ways to solve the problem.

Psychology is an effort to delve deeper into the nature, structure and functions of the psyche. Philosophy is an effort to delve deeper into the nature, structure and functions of every entity and psychology is only a branch of it. Aristotle divided philosophy into 6 branches: Metaphysics (concerning existence, ontology, and knowing, epistemology), Physics (concerning properties and relations among material objects including plants and animals, called physics, chemistry, zoology, botany, etc today), Logic (concerning methods of inference including mathematics, statistics etc today), Politics (of ideal social systems and their organization, economics, political science, sociology, etc), Ethics (concerning ideal conduct of human beings at individual and social level) and Aesthetics (concerning ideal forms (that may include all arts such as painting, sculpture, architecture, singing, dancing, music and so on). Kautilya (in his Arthshastra) talks of Aanwikshiki (relating to the 6 orthodox philosophical systems like Nyaya, Vaisheshik, Sankhya, etc and the seventh one that is heterodox or lokayata), Trayi (including the Vedas and the Vedangas and the Puranas, etc including all shruties and smrities), Vaartaa (economic matters such as agriculture, animal husbandry, manufacturing, trade, etc) and Dandaniti (politics, administration, law, governance etc.). In this system, psychology will fall into Aanwikshiki. Vaisheshika of Kanada, Yoga of Patanjali and Mana, atma, etc of Sankhya will take care of psychology. Patanjali began with: Yogaschittavritti nirodhah. Kanada considers Mana and Aatma as Dravya with various properties (guna). There has been a good interaction among standard philosophers (such as Arthur Schopenhauer) and psychologists (such as Carl F Jung) on the nature of the psyche. It is worth reading. They are not all wrong that they give the same degree PhD (Doctor of Philosophy) in all branches of learning.

Psychology is a discipline attempting to use the techniques of science to study the human mind, how it relates to behavior, how it relates to physiology (brain), When done well, it is as rigorous as any of the sciences. When it is not done well, it is a hotbed of claptrap ideas masquerading as science. A complicating factor is that there is a difference between those whose primary interest is doing psychotherapy, and those whose interest is doing basic research. I have known psychotherapists who were good at the science, and others who were more interested in their own opinions. I think those with more taste for the science are more prone to head to the research track. I think some of the early work, Freud, Jung, et. al., mixed a great deal more personal philosophy into the observations, and leaned on that instead of proper research design. As a result, their work is much more of a mixed bag. Another complicating factor is that all (as of this date) known  researchers are also psychological beings. There is an element of testing rulers by using a ruler  - this does not invalidate all psychology research, but it is a factor that must be properly included in the design, lest observer bias take hold. Philosophy is inherently a different discipline, using different methods to explore a wider range of subjects.

Philosophy is human expression inspired by love for knowledge. A philosopher may gurantee practicality of his philosophy for others, but he still says because of the revolution he experienced in his life. Philosopher is more likely to live by his philosophy. Generally philosophy has morals as prime subject. Somethings are sacred. Focus is on self. People connect with philosophy through their own experiences. The words must appeal the individual to have an effect on him. psychology on the other hand is organised knowledge of human behavior, mind and connections with other body processes/parts. Its tested and proved to be practical for every human. Psychologist adds to psychology because of his career, study and practice. Psychologists own views are not important if they don't agree with the standard practices. A psychologist no matter what is tiny in front of entire psychology, hence hard to master and live by. Morals are themselves subject to analysis and study. Nothing is held sacred. People connect with psychology through study and observation (of self and others). Focus is on others (not just self).

Modern Psychology and Philosophy are two different subjects of study and research, but the origin of psychology is found in Philosophy. Among the earliest arguments relating Psychology was one between Aristotle and Plato around the 3rd and 4th centuries BC, about the role of nature and the role of nurture in psychological development.[1] The first laboratory of Psychology established in India was in the Department of Philosophy, University of Calcutta in 1916. The following year, 1917, the first Department of Psychology was established in the University. Now, the modern Psychology has taken a far different route and is a complete discipline in itself, while Philosophy remains a prominent discipline in itself, as always. Psychology is the scientific study of human behaviour, mental processes and experiences in different contexts; while Philosophy is defined as the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence. Psychology attempts to study the structure[2], function[3] and the behavioural origin of the human mind[4], while Philosophy is a critical analysis of fundamental beliefs and values. Both originate from the same roots, but Psychology, as per the needs, has taken a scientific background while Philosophy remains a humanist field of study.[5] Footnotes[1] 1.2 The Evolution of Psychology: History, Approaches, and Questions[2] Structuralism (psychology) - Wikipedia[3] Functional psychology - Wikipedia[4] Behaviorism - Wikipedia[5] The Difference Between Philosophy and Psychology

Thanks, Vishwas Londhe for the A2A. A simple way to put it might be that philosophy is about establishing what's right about human thought and psychology is about what goes wrong with human thought. Philosophy covers the organized study of life, and potentially a life beyond. Psychology covers the organized study of the mind. Philosophy looks at how we relate to knowledge. It looks at what it's possible to know, at whether it is even possible to know anything fully. It considers the tools that seem to work in logic, and the traps that can derail logical thought. Philosophy leads to an ontology and that leads to epistemology. Psychology is the study of why we think as we do and behave as we do, and what goes wrong with our minds, leading us to abnormal and sometimes self-destructive behavior.

Psychology is a science. Science is a method of studying the natural world. Any method of study requires some philosophical assumptions. Science is no exception. Philosophy outlines how we come to knowledge and answers a lot of questions about existence and the metaphysical. It also leads us to more questions. Now philosophy is fairly bad at giving us singular, straight answers. But that's what I was saying: assumptions. You can't, for example, say you know why a person did something... if you don't believe anyone outside you exists (solipsism). Psychology, as a science, is more concerned with getting to the bottom of human behavior and mental capacity, usually under the philosophical assumption that we can figure out those things naturalistically, that it is as at least in part deterministic, and that we can trust logic and evidence to guide us to those answers (as all science should.) Hopefully that clears up the relationship of philosophy and science. At one point, philosophy was science. It was superceded in terms of achieving the goals required from science.

Philosophy tends to be an investigation of reality using logic and reason.  Although there is no reason why it has to be strictly via reason--except that it provides common ground and a way to evaluate arguments. Wikipedia highlights: Philosophy is the study of the general and fundamental nature of reality, existence, knowledge, values, reason, mind, and language. Source: Philosophy Psychology looks at human thinking, feeling, and behavior (individual and in groups) via systematic study. Wikipedia highlights: Psychologists explore concepts such as perception, cognition, attention, emotion, intelligence, phenomenology, motivation, brain functioning, personality, behavior, and interpersonal relationships, including psychological resilience, family resilience, and other areas. Psychologists of diverse orientations also consider the unconscious mind.[5] Psychologists employ empirical methods to infer causal and correlational relationships between psychosocial variables. In addition, or in opposition, to employing empirical and deductive methods, some—especially clinical and counseling psychologists—at times rely upon symbolic interpretation and other inductive techniques. Psychology has been described as a "hub science",[6] with psychological findings linking to research and perspectives from the social sciences, natural sciences, medicine, humanities, and philosophy. While psychological knowledge is often applied to the assessment and treatment of mental health problems, it is also directed towards understanding and solving problems in several spheres of human activity. By many accounts psychology ultimately aims to benefit society. Source: Psychology

Philosophy is concerned with knowledge and wisdom (the literal translation from the Greek is love of wisdom); what can we know, what is truth, how can we know, what is knowledge. It also costs many more abstract questions such as the meaning of existence and the nature of free will and responsibility. Psychology is the study of the mind and human behavior (translation from the Greek is study of the spirit).  Not to be confused with Neuroscience, which is the study of how the brain works, psychology is concerned with how the mind works and how that informs and affects behavior. (Although, nowadays, psychologists would stress that they don't use behaviorist models of mind). In practical terms, philosophy is more interested in exploring ideas critically and systematically looking for errors in reasoning or logic, whereas psychology is more about collecting data and making predictions about, or explaining behavior.

Psychology is an empirical science - a practice while philosophy is a theoretical science, it seeks to understand what we do when we do something; to bring a self reflective awareness or understanding of a practical art. Philosophy develops a framework for critical thinking and valid knowledge and undertakes the scrutiny of concepts tacitly assumed by an empirical science or even in everyday life. Philosophy has no subject matter in particular; it has a broad scope and by scrutinizing every aspect of human life whether that be in physical sciences or social sciences; it brings a synoptic vision of life or a world view in place. Study of philosophy is beneficial even to a practicing scientist to come to terms with his subject; a science aims at knowledge of a particular domain, while philosophy seeks to understand how we have such a knowledge or do we have knowledge at all. It can contribute in both understanding of knowledge and in advancement of knowledge.

When you study your beliefs, and build upon (and even correcting) those beliefs logically to have a self consistent model of your observations (which may include observations about psychology) you are studying philosophy. When you scientifically study the processes that give rise to human behaviour (which may include why and how we study philosophy) it's psychology. Psychology is necessarily a science, on the other hand a particular school of philosophy may reject all science. Edit: At the end of the day, it's all about how you in define Psychology and Philosophy, and these definitions can change with time. How you think about everything or anything, shouldn't be bound by these definitions.

On one of my birthdays, I received a book on philosophy as gift. I was surprised. Then my friend said that he remembered it as philosophy when I said psychology. Another friend said, “ You are into philosophy and all.” I was confused again because I clearly mentioned that I read psychology books and not philosophy. They are totally two different streams with no scope for confusion. Philosophy is musings of different people on outlook towards life and the other is a scientific process of understanding human behavior.

Psychology is what happens in your mind, head and attitudes when you ask this question - philosophy is reflecting on your question, questioning it in at least 9 Socratic ways and attempt to dissolve it by means of a meaningful response - Bad philosophy do not use the following PHILOSOPHY – Aims, Methods, Rationale (PHILOSOPHY – Aims, Methods, Rationale) to realize the following imilar to PHILOSOPHY = PHILO SOPHOS = LOVE OF WISDOM with enlarged Appendices (imilar to PHILOSOPHY = PHILO SOPHOS = LOVE OF WISDOM with enlarged Appendices) by means of the following Philosophizing is part of the Process/es of Theorizing (Philosophizing is part of the Process/es of Theorizing) GOOD philosophy consist of the above practices

I think by definition. The root word “philosophy” (phila sophia) is “love of wisdom,” to include “a search for truth.” Arguably, each individual has a perspective regarding truth and wisdom, thus meaning that each of us have at least an informal philosophy as part of our own psychology. The classical and formal philosophy has branches and is a “whole” with “parts” like everything else. Psychology, usually refers to a local psyche’. However, the exploration into a non local psyche’ is part of this field of discipline, even becoming as if a murky mixture with philosophy, and even quantum metaphysics. “… as scientific investigators of the situation in which we find ourselves, we cannot, of course, neglect to study a mass of phenomena so large and so obtrusive as to constitute, to first appearance, the whole of the world we know. Consequently, a separate science has gradually arisen which endeavors to deal with these and other of the rather bulky leaving of physics. This science is called ‘Psychology’, and the facts with which it deals are dubbed ‘mental’, or, more commonly, ‘Psychical’ (J.W. Dunne, An Experiment With Time p 18); So, ‘psychology’ inspects “inward” processes as if studying the collisions in a bubble chamber on a subjective illusionary stage within the few cubic centimeters of the skull. These can provide clues, glimpses, revelations, insights, into the philosophical view of the nature of everything in existence/non existence. The ‘psyche’ is an invisible “formless.”
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Gyselle Hernandez Salmeron

response.answer_text: Western philosophy is a literary genre which originated in ancient Greece about 2,500 years ago. Over all this time, philosophers have explored hundreds of topics including the nature of the human mind. Psychology is a social science which arose in Europe in the 19th century (its roots were in the discipline of medicine). Psychology as we know it today is actually two disciplines. There is research psychology, a practice that is fairly close to a natural science and involves experiments and expensive technology to determine how the brain functions (and misfunctions in some people). Then there is clinical psychology, which involves training therapists to work with groups or individuals who are suffering from emotional pain or destructive behaviors. Naturally, philosophy and psychology still address the nature of the human mind. Ancient questions such as “What is the best life for a human being to live?” can be explored and answered by professionals in either field.

Philosophy is like water, it can fill any vessel. You could consider psychology one type of vessel. Physics, another. Music, art, economics, literature, anthropology are all forms which can be philosophically informed. How could a 'lover of wisdom' not want to understand how their own mind works, especially since by understanding the sole tool (their mind) by which a philosopher performs their work, their work can be improved?

Hi Gyselle: Many years ago before the 19th century development of psychology as a science, it was always taught as a discipline of philosophy. Psyche in Greek means mind or personality and therefore it was philosophers writing about what makes up the human mind and why do humans behave as we do. It also had to do with character development and moral behavior , why people do good or bad things to each other. After and during the Enlightenment, Wilhelm Wundt and others began to use experimentation to research why humans act the way they do by setting up experiments in a lab or studying human behavior by personality types etc. No longer was it using pure logic and empirical observation by philosophers to establish our “psyches” but controlled research to see what condition actually affect behavior and positing hypotheses to be proven. It became less conjecture and more scientifically verified by the methods of research. The same is true today. Psychology is taught based on empirical research and its application versus philosophy which is both a rational and observational discipline but no experiments. Much of psychology still requires some understanding of systems of philosophy but less so that in previous years.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Gyselle Hernandez Salmeron

response.answer_text: From above pictorial explanation,I can understand only one thing, that Philosophy is rationale argument about problems, such as those connected with reality, existence, knowledge, values, reason, mind and language where as Psychology is  the scientific study of mental functions and behaviors.   Philosophy is very vast domain and Psychology is organized study. Philosophy Vs. Psychology  Thanks for asking Vishwas Londhe Sir!

Western philosophy in nature is Plato defined metaphysics like geometry and logic. It’s about axioms, ideals and beliefs. It’s abstract and supernatural. Psychology is relationism, a study of human relationship and behavior in the social reality. There we have social psychology not social philosophy in the western tradition. In comparison, the Chinese philosophy, e.g., yin-yang relationship and Confucianism, is all relationism. Hence the Chinese philosophy is really social and political psychology in the western definition. I call it the real philosophy. Similarly, religion of Buddhism is more psychology than philosophy to me as well. I was gonna recommend a new field but checked and found it, Political psychology. It’s certainly not as famous as political philosophy and political science, but is really needed in the western free world to my opinion. Western philosophy is supernatural and science doesn’t provide guidance in moral values. Neither gives realistic insight in social politics. Of course the young American pragmatism is an exception.

In Psychology, you study human mind and behavior where philosophy more concerned with finding solutions for complicated questions such as Existence, values, Real and imaginary things. In fact, psychology is originated from philosophy as you can see both deals with people mind and lives this is the reason these both bodies overlap sometimes though they are differentiated into two separate bodies. Key differences:  Reference: https://www.edology.com/blog/psychology/what-can-i-do-with-a-psychology-degree/ http://www.sparknotes.com/psychology/psych101/researchmethods/section2/ Hope it helps you!!!!

Psychology is the study of the human mind and behavior.    How do people process sensory information?    What role do emotions play in cognition, and vice versa?    How can we treat mental illnesses?   These are psychological issues.    Philosophy is the critical analysis, and sometimes normative presentation, of significant abstractions.   What do we mean when we say that we "know" something?    What do we mean when we say that something is "real"?    Is mental illness a fact or a metaphor?    These are philosophical issues.

Psychology - see dictionaries - the scientific (empirical and related to empirical phenomena?) study of the human mind and its functions, especially those affecting behaviour in a given context. synonyms: study of the mind, science of the mind, science of the personality, study of the mental processes "she has a degree in psychology" Philosophy - the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence, especially when considered as an academic discipline. philosophy Meaning in the Cambridge English Dictionary 1. the use of reason in understanding such things (in a general, universal manner , or the often by analysis of particular ideas and concepts in the so-called analytic approach or style or descriptions by means of ideas and concepts - Continental style or approach) as the nature of the real world and existence, the use and limits of knowledge, and the principles of moral judgment: 2. a group of theories and ideas related to the understanding of a particular subject: 3. a particular system…. Learn more.

Psychology is more practical and probably more useful on a sort of day to day basis. Psychology is primarily the study of how our brains work - whether on the large scale of minds, emotions and so on or the very detailed scale of neuropsychology.  It is (at least arguably) a science. It makes some use of experiment.  Philosophy is the study of "big ideas".  It is in no respect a science.

Philosopy is about knowing, or figuring out, the nature of some reality. If something is true, good, or real, or false, bad or fake, philosphy asks why and how can you prove it. Philosopy is the quest for the ultimate truth behind life's most important questions, accross all disciplines, including science, epistemology, ethics, theology, and the arts. And don't talk gibberish, because everything is neatly bound by the rules of logic. Psychology is just about people and why they think and act the way they do in different situations and with various illnesses. It's a discipline more about people than anything else, where the philosopher is mostly concerned with the rest of the universe. For the most part, philosophers look out, and psychologists look in.

Philpsophy comes from the greek Philo “the love of” Sophy “Wisdom”. It is a passion for learning Wisdom. Philosophy is involved in understanding the relativity's and interconnections that exist, between life's realities (And the mysterious) relative to the biosphere of our existence, and the Universe. Psychology is trying to relate to and understand human behavior, based upon and subject to, the observers interpretations, and the assumptions they (Psychologist's) have made in regard to their observations (Of human, primate, and animal behavior); with a view of developing an overall and generalized overview/theory of the Human Psyche and its behavioral mechanisms.
Both psychology and philosophy try to describe human condition… but roughly speaking , psychology tries to answer, why humans are not happy, when philosophy tries to make humans happy… all the best.

'Psychology' is an academic discipline and an "applied science" which seeks to understand individuals and groups by studying mind and behavior.  'Philosophy'  is the study of general and fundamental problems, such as those connected with reality, existence, knowledge, values, reason, mind, and language.  The word 'Philosophy' literally means 'love of wisdom'.  To my knowledge, Philosophy is the mother discipline of all studies. Till about 19th century, there was no such term as science. What was studied in universities was called 'natural philosophy', the branch of philosophy that pertains to  the work of analysis and synthesis of common experience and argumentation to explain or describe nature.   The term science, as in natural science, gained its modern meaning when acquiring knowledge through experiments (special experiences) under the scientific method became its own specialized branch of study apart from natural philosophy.  So to sum it all up, Science is that branch of philosophy (or at least science has it's root in natural philosophy) which deals with acquiring knowledge through experiments. Psychology is that branch of Science that studies mind and behavior.  Hope this helps :)

Psychology is real thing that one can see in oneself or others. Example: Getting angry.Philosophy is the attitude that one can have or ideas come by thinking process to make oneself or others better. Example: Finding ideas or ways to control angry Psychology is the mental characteristics or attitude of a person or group.Philosophy is the attitude or ideas that acts as a guiding principle for behaviour.

Their difference can be discerned from their etymology. “Philosophy” comes from the Greek words “philos” (love) and sophos” (wisdom) and translates into “a love of wisdom.” Philosophers inquire into the nature of existence generally in three main categories: (1) ontology (the science or nature of being); (2); epistemology (the science or nature of knowledge); and (3) ethics (inquiring into what is a good —moral— life). ”Psychology” derives from the Greek words for soul (“psyche”) and reason or science (“logos”). It is the study of human consciousness, mind, and spirit. All philosophers are likely to be interested in psychology (at least to some extent), but not all psychologists are interested in traditional philosophical questions as part of their professional calling.

Philosophy has no pretensions of being a science and even critiques science and in that sense it is more all-encompassing. Psychology on the other hand aspires to scientific veracity and truth, without being self-reflective. What is vital on a personal level is not to confuse between the two. One's relationships, immediate thoughts, feelings etc, that would come under the ambit of psychology, must be allowed to breath, relieved from the ramshackles of academic philosophy.  Psychological analysis  can singe, but philosophical analysis consumes.

Some odd answers on this one, but let's break it down. Philosophy studies the nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.  Psychology studies the human mind and its functions, especially those relating to behavior. They're two very different fields of study, with some, but very little, overlap.

Philosophers and psychologists both share an interest in many overlapping areas of human concern. They also share a very similar vocabulary; mind, cognition, behavior, thoughts, emotions, etc. While Philosophy and psychology are both gigantic fields of study and overlap in many areas; historically, intellectually, and methodologically, they do so from different perspectives. Teasing out the similarities and difference can be quite confusing and frustrating. The best I could say is that Psychology as a branch of science is grounded in hypothesis, experimentation, and evidence, the scientific method. While philosophies are more speculative but where they come closer together in the theoretical domain. All of that being said, it might be best to think of philosophers as preoccupied with asking and answering the ultimate ‘why’ questions and the scientist interested in solving the problems of how things are not why they are.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Gyselle Hernandez Salmeron

response.answer_text: The way I see it, philosophy is a world view and psychology is a science. They have both seemed connected to me for a long time, and I suppose so would be the case for anyone with questions. One answers the questions of the world, whereas one delves inwards for the answers. Because of the ambiguous nature of philosophy, there are more unproven theories formulated in the subject. Psychology is seen as more practical, applicable in daily life.

response.answer_text: Thank you for posting this incredibly dumb question that could easily be answered by looking at the definition of the two. I have been noting that easily more than half of the questions asked here are trolls and most of the rest are repeated or the sort of question a 5 year old might answer. The number of serious and sensible question is very small, not worth trawling through the dross. You have saved me a lot of time.
